data.ans: Elements that are generally hard, lustrous, malleable, and ductile.
Elements that are generally soft, dull, and brittle.

data.que: Give an example of a metal.
data.ans: Iron (Fe)

data.que: Give an example of a non-metal.
data.ans: Carbon (C)
The ability of a metal to be beaten into thin sheets.
The ability of a metal to be drawn into wires.

data.que: Are metals good conductors of heat and electricity?
data.ans: Yes

data.que: Are non-metals good conductors of heat and electricity?
data.ans: No, they are generally poor conductors.
Elements that have properties of both metals and non-metals.

data.que: Give an example of a metalloid.
data.ans: Silicon (Si)
Homogeneous mixtures of two or more metals, or a metal and a non-metal.

data.que: Give an example of an alloy.
data.ans: Steel (Iron + Carbon)
A list of metals arranged in order of their decreasing reactivity.
Compounds formed by the transfer of electrons between metals and non-metals.
Compounds formed by the sharing of electrons between non-metals.
A naturally occurring rock or sediment from which a metal can be extracted.
The impurities present in an ore.
Heating an ore in the presence of air to convert it to oxide.
Heating an ore in the absence of air to remove volatile impurities.
The process of reducing a metal oxide to obtain the metal.
Coating iron or steel with zinc to prevent corrosion.
Forming a thick oxide layer on aluminum to prevent corrosion.
An alloy of mercury with another metal.

data.que: Why is gold used in jewelry?
data.ans: It is lustrous and resistant to corrosion.
A mixture of concentrated nitric acid and hydrochloric acid, optimally in a molar ratio of 1:3.

data.que: Why is sodium kept immersed in kerosene oil?
data.ans: It is highly reactive and reacts vigorously with air and water.
